column2: At that moment there was a movement just beside the President; a voice was heard crying:--
column3: At that moment there was a movement just beside the President; a voice was heard crying:--

column2: Brevet!	Brevet!
column3: false

column2: Chenildieu!
column3: Chenildieu!

column2: Cochepaille! look here!"
column3: Cochepaille! look here!"

column2: All who heard that voice were chilled, so lamentable and terrible was it; all eyes were turned to the point whence it had proceeded.
column3: All who heard that voice were chilled, so lamentable and terrible was it; all eyes were turned to the point whence it had proceeded.

column2: A man, placed among the privileged spectators who were seated behind the court, had just risen, had pushed open the half-door which separated the tribunal from the audience, and was standing in the middle of the hall; the President, the district-attorney, M. Bamatabois, twenty persons, recognized him, and exclaimed in concert:--
column3: A man, placed among the privileged spectators who were seated behind the court, had just risen, had pushed open the half door which separated the tribunal from the audience, and was standing in the middle of the hall; the President, the district attorney, m Bamatabois, twenty persons, recognized him, and exclaimed in concert:--

column2: M.	M.
column3: false

column2: Madeleine!"
column3: Madeleine!"

column2: CHAPTER XI--CHAMPMATHIEU MORE AND MORE ASTONISHED
column3: CHAPTER eleven-c h a m p m a t h i e u MORE AND MORE ASTONISHED

column2: It was he, in fact.
column3: It was he, in fact.

column2: The clerk's lamp illumined his countenance.
column3: The clerk's lamp illumined his countenance.

column2: He held his hat in his hand; there was no disorder in his clothing; his coat was carefully buttoned; he was very pale, and he trembled slightly; his hair, which had still been gray on his arrival in Arras, was now entirely white: it had turned white during the hour he had sat there.
column3: He held his hat in his hand; there was no disorder in his clothing; his coat was carefully buttoned; he was very pale, and he trembled slightly; his hair, which had still been gray on his arrival in Arras, was now entirely white: it had turned white during the hour he had sat there.

column2: All heads were raised: the sensation was indescribable; there was a momentary hesitation in the audience, the voice had been so heart-rending; the man who stood there appeared so calm that they did not understand at first.
column3: All heads were raised: the sensation was indescribable; there was a momentary hesitation in the audience, the voice had been so heart rending; the man who stood there appeared so calm that they did not understand at first.

column2: They asked themselves whether he had indeed uttered that cry; they could not believe that that tranquil man had been the one to give that terrible outcry.
column3: They asked themselves whether he had indeed uttered that cry; they could not believe that that tranquil man had been the one to give that terrible outcry.

column2: This indecision only lasted a few seconds.
column3: This indecision only lasted a few seconds.

column2: Even before the President and the district-attorney could utter a word, before the ushers and the gendarmes could make a gesture, the man whom all still called, at that moment, M. Madeleine, had advanced towards the witnesses Cochepaille, Brevet, and Chenildieu.
column3: Even before the President and the district attorney could utter a word, before the ushers and the gendarmes could make a gesture, the man whom all still called, at that moment, m Madeleine, had advanced towards the witnesses Cochepaille, Brevet, and Chenildieu.

column2: Do you not recognize me? said he.
column3: Do you not recognize me? said he.

column2: All three remained speechless, and indicated by a sign of the head that they did not know him.
column3: All three remained speechless, and indicated by a sign of the head that they did not know him.

column2: Cochepaille, who was intimidated, made a military salute.
column3: Cochepaille, who was intimidated, made a military salute.

column2: M. Madeleine turned towards the jury and the court, and said in a gentle voice:--
column3: M. Madeleine turned towards the jury and the court, and said in a gentle voice:--

column2: Gentlemen of the jury, order the prisoner to be released!	Gentlemen of the jury, order the prisoner to be released!
column3: true

column2: Mr. President, have me arrested.
column3: mr President, have me arrested.

column2: He is not the man whom you are in search of; it is I: I am Jean Valjean."
column3: He is not the man whom you are in search of; it is I: I am Jean Valjean."

column2: Not a mouth breathed; the first commotion of astonishment had been followed by a silence like that of the grave; those within the hall experienced that sort of religious terror which seizes the masses when something grand has been done.
column3: Not a mouth breathed; the first commotion of astonishment had been followed by a silence like that of the grave; those within the hall experienced that sort of religious terror which seizes the masses when something grand has been done.

column2: In the meantime, the face of the President was stamped with sympathy and sadness; he had exchanged a rapid sign with the district-attorney and a few low-toned words with the assistant judges; he addressed the public, and asked in accents which all understood:--
column3: In the meantime, the face of the President was stamped with sympathy and sadness; he had exchanged a rapid sign with the district attorney and a few low toned words with the assistant judges; he addressed the public, and asked in accents which all understood:--

column2: Is there a physician present?
column3: Is there a physician present?

column2: The district-attorney took the word:--
column3: The district attorney took the word:--

column2: Gentlemen of the jury, the very strange and unexpected incident which disturbs the audience inspires us, like yourselves, only with a sentiment which it is unnecessary for us to express.	Gentlemen of the jury, the very strange and unexpected incident which disturbs the audience inspires us, like yourselves, only with a sentiment which it is unnecessary for us to express.
column3: true

column2: You all know, by reputation at least, the honorable M. Madeleine, mayor of M. sur M.; if there is a physician in the audience, we join the President in requesting him to attend to M. Madeleine, and to conduct him to his home."
column3: You all know, by reputation at least, the honorable m Madeleine, mayor of m sur m; if there is a physician in the audience, we join the President in requesting him to attend to m Madeleine, and to conduct him to his home."

column2: M. Madeleine did not allow the district-attorney to finish; he interrupted him in accents full of suavity and authority.
column3: M. Madeleine did not allow the district attorney to finish; he interrupted him in accents full of suavity and authority.

column2: These are the words which he uttered; here they are literally, as they were written down, immediately after the trial by one of the witnesses to this scene, and as they now ring in the ears of those who heard them nearly forty years ago:--
column3: These are the words which he uttered; here they are literally, as they were written down, immediately after the trial by one of the witnesses to this scene, and as they now ring in the ears of those who heard them nearly forty years ago:--

column2: I thank you, Mr. District-Attorney, but I am not mad; you shall see; you were on the point of committing a great error; release this man!	I thank you, mr District Attorney, but I am not mad; you shall see; you were on the point of committing a great error; release this man!
column3: true

column2: I am fulfilling a duty; I am that miserable criminal.
column3: I am fulfilling a duty; I am that miserable criminal.

column2: I am the only one here who sees the matter clearly, and I am telling you the truth.
column3: I am the only one here who sees the matter clearly, and I am telling you the truth.

column2: God, who is on high, looks down on what I am doing at this moment, and that suffices.
column3: God, who is on high, looks down on what I am doing at this moment, and that suffices.

column2: You can take me, for here I am: but I have done my best; I concealed myself under another name; I have become rich; I have become a mayor; I have tried to re-enter the ranks of the honest.
column3: You can take me, for here I am: but I have done my best; I concealed myself under another name; I have become rich; I have become a mayor; I have tried to re-enter the ranks of the honest.

column2: It seems that that is not to be done.
column3: It seems that that is not to be done.

column2: In short, there are many things which I cannot tell.
column3: In short, there are many things which I cannot tell.

column2: I will not narrate the story of my life to you; you will hear it one of these days.
column3: I will not narrate the story of my life to you; you will hear it one of these days.

column2: I robbed Monseigneur the Bishop, it is true; it is true that I robbed Little Gervais; they were right in telling you that Jean Valjean was a very vicious wretch.
column3: I robbed Monseigneur the Bishop, it is true; it is true that I robbed Little Gervais; they were right in telling you that Jean Valjean was a very vicious wretch.

column2: Perhaps it was not altogether his fault.
column3: Perhaps it was not altogether his fault.

column2: Listen, honorable judges! a man who has been so greatly humbled as I have has neither any remonstrances to make to Providence, nor any advice to give to society; but, you see, the infamy from which I have tried to escape is an injurious thing; the galleys make the convict what he is; reflect upon that, if you please.
column3: Listen, honorable judges! a man who has been so greatly humbled as I have has neither any remonstrances to make to Providence, nor any advice to give to society; but, you see, the infamy from which I have tried to escape is an injurious thing; the galleys make the convict what he is; reflect upon that, if you please.

column2: Before going to the galleys, I was a poor peasant, with very little intelligence, a sort of idiot; the galleys wrought a change in me.
column3: Before going to the galleys, I was a poor peasant, with very little intelligence, a sort of idiot; the galleys wrought a change in me.

column2: I was stupid; I became vicious: I was a block of wood; I became a firebrand.
column3: I was stupid; I became vicious: I was a block of wood; I became a firebrand.

column2: Later on, indulgence and kindness saved me, as severity had ruined me.
column3: Later on, indulgence and kindness saved me, as severity had ruined me.

column2: But, pardon me, you cannot understand what I am saying.
column3: But, pardon me, you cannot understand what I am saying.

column2: You will find at my house, among the ashes in the fireplace, the forty-sou piece which I stole, seven years ago, from little Gervais.
column3: You will find at my house, among the ashes in the fireplace, the forty sou piece which I stole, seven years ago, from little Gervais.

column2: I have nothing farther to add; take me.
column3: I have nothing farther to add; take me.

column2: Good God! the district-attorney shakes his head; you say, 'M. Madeleine has gone mad!' you do not believe me! that is distressing.
column3: Good God! the district attorney shakes his head; you say, 'M. Madeleine has gone mad!' you do not believe me! that is distressing.

column2: Do not, at least, condemn this man!
column3: Do not, at least, condemn this man!

column2: What! these men do not recognize me!
column3: What! these men do not recognize me!

column2: I wish Javert were here; he would recognize me."
column3: I wish Javert were here; he would recognize me."

column2: Nothing can reproduce the sombre and kindly melancholy of tone which accompanied these words.
column3: Nothing can reproduce the sombre and kindly melancholy of tone which accompanied these words.

column2: He turned to the three convicts, and said:--
column3: He turned to the three convicts, and said:--

column2: Well, I recognize you; do you remember, Brevet?
column3: Well, I recognize you; do you remember, Brevet?

column2: He paused, hesitated for an instant, and said:--
column3: He paused, hesitated for an instant, and said:--

column2: Do you remember the knitted suspenders with a checked pattern which you wore in the galleys?
column3: Do you remember the knitted suspenders with a checked pattern which you wore in the galleys?

column2: Brevet gave a start of surprise, and surveyed him from head to foot with a frightened air.
column3: Brevet gave a start of surprise, and surveyed him from head to foot with a frightened air.

column2: He continued:--
column3: He continued:--

column2: Chenildieu, you who conferred on yourself the name of 'Jenie-Dieu,' your whole right shoulder bears a deep burn, because you one day laid your shoulder against the chafing-dish full of coals, in order to efface the three letters T. F. P., which are still visible, nevertheless; answer, is this true?
column3: Chenildieu, you who conferred on yourself the name of 'Jenie Dieu,' your whole right shoulder bears a deep burn, because you one day laid your shoulder against the chafing dish full of coals, in order to efface the three letters t f p, which are still visible, nevertheless; answer, is this true?

column2: It is true, said Chenildieu.
column3: It is true, said Chenildieu.

column2: He addressed himself to Cochepaille:--
column3: He addressed himself to Cochepaille:--

column2: Cochepaille, you have, near the bend in your left arm, a date stamped in blue letters with burnt powder; the date is that of the landing of the Emperor at Cannes, March 1, 1815; pull up your sleeve!
column3: Cochepaille, you have, near the bend in your left arm, a date stamped in blue letters with burnt powder; the date is that of the landing of the Emperor at Cannes, march first eighteen fifteen; pull up your sleeve!

column2: Cochepaille pushed up his sleeve; all eyes were focused on him and on his bare arm.
column3: Cochepaille pushed up his sleeve; all eyes were focused on him and on his bare arm.

column2: A gendarme held a light close to it; there was the date.
column3: A gendarme held a light close to it; there was the date.

column2: The unhappy man turned to the spectators and the judges with a smile which still rends the hearts of all who saw it whenever they think of it.
column3: The unhappy man turned to the spectators and the judges with a smile which still rends the hearts of all who saw it whenever they think of it.

column2: It was a smile of triumph; it was also a smile of despair.
column3: It was a smile of triumph; it was also a smile of despair.

column2: You see plainly, he said, "that I am Jean Valjean."
column3: You see plainly, he said, "that I am Jean Valjean."

column2: In that chamber there were no longer either judges, accusers, nor gendarmes; there was nothing but staring eyes and sympathizing hearts. No one recalled any longer the part that each might be called upon to play; the district-attorney forgot he was there for the purpose of prosecuting, the President that he was there to preside, the counsel for the defence that he was there to defend.
column3: In that chamber there were no longer either judges, accusers, nor gendarmes; there was nothing but staring eyes and sympathizing hearts. No one recalled any longer the part that each might be called upon to play; the district attorney forgot he was there for the purpose of prosecuting, the President that he was there to preside, the counsel for the defence that he was there to defend.

column2: It was a striking circumstance that no question was put, that no authority intervened.
column3: It was a striking circumstance that no question was put, that no authority intervened.

column2: The peculiarity of sublime spectacles is, that they capture all souls and turn witnesses into spectators.
column3: The peculiarity of sublime spectacles is, that they capture all souls and turn witnesses into spectators.

column2: No one, probably, could have explained what he felt; no one, probably, said to himself that he was witnessing the splendid outburst of a grand light: all felt themselves inwardly dazzled.
column3: No one, probably, could have explained what he felt; no one, probably, said to himself that he was witnessing the splendid outburst of a grand light: all felt themselves inwardly dazzled.

column2: It was evident that they had Jean Valjean before their eyes.
column3: It was evident that they had Jean Valjean before their eyes.

column2: That was clear.
column3: That was clear.

column2: The appearance of this man had sufficed to suffuse with light that matter which had been so obscure but a moment previously, without any further explanation: the whole crowd, as by a sort of electric revelation, understood instantly and at a single glance the simple and magnificent history of a man who was delivering himself up so that another man might not be condemned in his stead.
column3: The appearance of this man had sufficed to suffuse with light that matter which had been so obscure but a moment previously, without any further explanation: the whole crowd, as by a sort of electric revelation, understood instantly and at a single glance the simple and magnificent history of a man who was delivering himself up so that another man might not be condemned in his stead.

column2: The details, the hesitations, little possible oppositions, were swallowed up in that vast and luminous fact.
column3: The details, the hesitations, little possible oppositions, were swallowed up in that vast and luminous fact.

column2: It was an impression which vanished speedily, but which was irresistible at the moment.
column3: It was an impression which vanished speedily, but which was irresistible at the moment.

column2: I do not wish to disturb the court further, resumed Jean Valjean.
column3: I do not wish to disturb the court further, resumed Jean Valjean.

column2: I shall withdraw, since you do not arrest me.	I shall withdraw, since you do not arrest me.
column3: true

column2: I have many things to do. The district-attorney knows who I am; he knows whither I am going; he can have me arrested when he likes."
column3: I have many things to do. The district attorney knows who I am; he knows whither I am going; he can have me arrested when he likes."

column2: He directed his steps towards the door.
column3: He directed his steps towards the door.

column2: Not a voice was raised, not an arm extended to hinder him.
column3: Not a voice was raised, not an arm extended to hinder him.

column2: All stood aside.
column3: All stood aside.

column2: At that moment there was about him that divine something which causes multitudes to stand aside and make way for a man.
column3: At that moment there was about him that divine something which causes multitudes to stand aside and make way for a man.

column2: He traversed the crowd slowly.
column3: He traversed the crowd slowly.

column2: It was never known who opened the door, but it is certain that he found the door open when he reached it.
column3: It was never known who opened the door, but it is certain that he found the door open when he reached it.

column2: On arriving there he turned round and said:--
column3: On arriving there he turned round and said:--

column2: I am at your command, Mr. District-Attorney.
column3: I am at your command, mr District Attorney.

column2: Then he addressed the audience:--
column3: Then he addressed the audience:--

column2: All of you, all who are present--consider me worthy of pity, do you not?	All of you, all who are present-consider me worthy of pity, do you not?
column3: true

column2: Good God!
column3: Good God!

column2: When I think of what I was on the point of doing, I consider that I am to be envied.
column3: When I think of what I was on the point of doing, I consider that I am to be envied.

column2: Nevertheless, I should have preferred not to have had this occur."
column3: Nevertheless, I should have preferred not to have had this occur."

column2: He withdrew, and the door closed behind him as it had opened, for those who do certain sovereign things are always sure of being served by some one in the crowd.
column3: He withdrew, and the door closed behind him as it had opened, for those who do certain sovereign things are always sure of being served by some one in the crowd.

column2: Less than an hour after this, the verdict of the jury freed the said Champmathieu from all accusations; and Champmathieu, being at once released, went off in a state of stupefaction, thinking that all men were fools, and comprehending nothing of this vision.
column3: Less than an hour after this, the verdict of the jury freed the said Champmathieu from all accusations; and Champmathieu, being at once released, went off in a state of stupefaction, thinking that all men were fools, and comprehending nothing of this vision.
